What is a Herd?

The traditional mascot of Postgres is an elephant. Since elephants travel in herds, imagine a grouping of related Postgres instances as a single entity along these lines. In this context, a herd has a single leader (the primary) for several followers (the replicas).

For the purposes of this utility, a herd is a name given to these groupings. So long as the label differs, herds can contain any number of instances.

Example

Say we have a trading instance that's small and meant to be widely distributed, and an execution instance that's a large monolith. As a herd, trading is deployed on six server containers, which are all subscribed to a seventh. The execution herd, being much larger, has only the leader and a single follower. These are functionally distinct groupings, visualized by the herd name.
